transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Hello, thank you for participating in this interview. I'm going to ask you some questions about your health and experiences. Let's begin.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Hello Avery, thank you for being here today. I appreciate your willingness to share your experiences. I want to make sure you feel comfortable, so please let me know if there's anything you’d like to discuss or if you need a break at any point. 

To start, can you tell me about your overall health and any medical conditions you might have?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me a bit about yourself and your current life situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Of course! My name is Avery, and I'm 27 years old. I live in a rural area of Missouri, and I work as an administrative assistant. I have a high school diploma, and my job is pretty much the same every day. I would say my income is on the lower-middle side, which sometimes makes it hard to afford things, especially when it comes to healthcare.

I'm currently single and not really looking to change that right now. I do have some health concerns, including a history of otitis media, and I’ve had some experiences with pregnancy, including a miscarriage about a year ago. Right now, I'm not planning to have another pregnancy, and I use condoms for contraception, although I have to admit, I’m not always consistent with that.

I also tend to lead a pretty sedentary lifestyle and smoke occasionally, which I'm not proud of. Access to healthcare is a challenge for me, so I don’t go to the doctor as often as I probably should. That's a bit about me! How about you?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your pregnancy or pregnancies? When did you first learn you were pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Sure! My first pregnancy was about a year ago. I found out I was pregnant pretty early on—I think I was about six weeks along when I took the test. I remember feeling a mix of excitement and nervousness since it was unexpected. 

I went to see a healthcare provider for my initial appointment, but I didn’t have a lot of support in terms of regular check-ups because of my limited access to healthcare. Unfortunately, I had a miscarriage around the 10-week mark. That was really tough for me emotionally, and I didn’t really have anyone to talk to about it. 

Since then, I haven’t been planning to get pregnant again. I think the experience has made me a bit hesitant, and I’m focusing on other aspects of my life right now. Have you worked with others who have had similar experiences?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: When did you first seek prenatal care? What was that experience like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I first sought prenatal care shortly after I found out I was pregnant, which was around six weeks into my pregnancy. I was really nervous but also excited to be taking that step. The experience was a bit overwhelming, though. The clinic I went to was the only one nearby, and it was difficult to get an appointment because they were often busy. 

When I finally saw the healthcare provider, they were nice and tried to be supportive, but I felt like I didn’t get enough time to discuss all my concerns. I had a lot of questions, especially about what to expect and how to take care of myself during pregnancy, but I didn’t feel like I could ask everything I wanted. 

I was also worried about my financial situation, which added to my anxiety. Since I was underinsured, I was concerned about the costs of the visits and any tests that might be needed. I ended up going to just that one appointment before I had the miscarriage, and after that, I didn’t seek further medical help since I was dealing with the emotional aftermath. 

Overall, it was a bittersweet experience—I was excited to be pregnant but also felt lost in navigating the healthcare system. Have you heard from others about their experiences with prenatal care?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who is providing your prenatal care? Can you describe your relationship with your healthcare provider?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Avery: Since my pregnancy ended in miscarriage, I don't have a current healthcare provider for prenatal care. During my pregnancy, I went to the local clinic, which is the only option available in my area. The healthcare provider there was nice, but I didn’t feel like I had a strong relationship with them. 

They were supportive during the appointment, but I wish I had someone I could speak to more regularly and who could help me navigate my concerns and questions. I think having a more consistent provider would have made a difference, especially when it came to feeling reassured and informed about my pregnancy and health.

Now that I'm not planning to get pregnant again, I haven’t really looked for a new provider, especially since I don’t have health insurance that would cover many visits. I mostly just try to manage my health on my own, which isn’t always easy. 

If I were to seek care again in the future, I would want to find someone I could build a better relationship with, someone who would take the time to listen to my concerns. Have you encountered patients who feel similarly about their healthcare providers?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How often do you have prenatal appointments? Can you walk me through what a typical visit is like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Avery: Since I’ve only had that one prenatal appointment during my pregnancy, I can't really describe a typical visit from regular prenatal care. But I can tell you about what that appointment was like. 

When I arrived at the clinic, I had to fill out some paperwork, which felt a bit overwhelming since there were a lot of questions, and I was already feeling anxious. After waiting for a while, I was called back to see the healthcare provider. They did a quick check on my health, like measuring my blood pressure and weight, and asked me some questions about my medical history and any symptoms I was having.

During the visit, the provider did an ultrasound to confirm the pregnancy, which was a mix of excitement and nerves for me. They explained some basic things about what to expect in the coming weeks, but I felt like there wasn’t enough time to go over all my questions. I had concerns about my lifestyle, like my smoking and how to eat healthier, but I didn’t feel like I could dive deep into those topics.

I remember feeling rushed at times, which made it hard to absorb everything they were saying. After the appointment, I left feeling a bit more informed, but I still had a lot of lingering questions. 

Since I didn't go back for follow-up appointments due to the miscarriage, I can’t really say how often I would have had appointments or what they would have entailed. Ideally, I would have liked to have regular check-ins to monitor my health and get support throughout the pregnancy. Do you think having more frequent visits would help improve outcomes for patients like me?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you experienced any health concerns or complications during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Avery: During my pregnancy, I was fortunate that I didn't experience any major complications, but there were definitely some health concerns that weighed heavily on my mind. I had a history of otitis media, which is an ear infection issue I’ve dealt with for a while, and I was worried about how that might affect my pregnancy.

I also struggled with anxiety, especially after finding out I was pregnant. I was constantly worried about the health of the baby and whether I was doing everything right. I didn’t have any major physical complications, but the emotional toll was significant. 

After my miscarriage, I found myself reflecting on what could have been and whether I could have done something differently. I think that emotional aspect is often overlooked, and it’s just as important as physical health during pregnancy. 

I’ve heard from others that they also faced emotional challenges during their pregnancies, particularly if they were under stress or had a history of loss. It can be really tough. Have you found that emotional health is something that gets enough attention in prenatal care discussions?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What medications or supplements are you currently taking?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Avery: Right now, I'm not taking any medications or supplements regularly. After my miscarriage, I didn't really feel like I needed anything, especially since I haven't been planning another pregnancy. I do try to eat a balanced diet when I can, but I know that my nutrition isn't always the best. 

Before my pregnancy, I was taking some over-the-counter pain relievers occasionally for headaches or discomfort, but I haven’t been consistent with anything since then. I’ve thought about taking prenatal vitamins because I know they’re important, especially if I were to get pregnant again, but with my financial situation, it's tough to prioritize that. 

If I were to seek care again, I would definitely want to discuss what supplements or medications might be beneficial for me, especially considering my history with pregnancy and my overall health. Do you think there are specific vitamins or medications that are particularly important for women in my situation?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your diet and nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Avery: During my pregnancy, I tried to be mindful of my diet, but it was challenging. I know how important nutrition is for a healthy pregnancy, and I wanted to make sure I was eating the right things. However, being in a lower-middle-income situation, I often had to prioritize affordability over nutrition. 

I aimed to eat more fruits and vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins, but sometimes I ended up relying on convenience foods that weren't very healthy. I struggled with cravings too—especially for comfort foods—which sometimes led me to make less healthy choices. I also dealt with some nausea early on, which made it hard to eat anything at all.

I really wanted to take prenatal vitamins to support my nutrition, but I couldn’t always afford them, and that was a concern for me. I had read that they were important for the baby's development, but I didn’t know how to fit them into my budget. 

Looking back, I realize that I could have done better in terms of planning meals and making healthier choices, but I was also feeling a lot of stress and anxiety, which affected my appetite and motivation. I think having access to better nutrition education and resources would have really helped me during that time. 

Do you find that many women in similar situations struggle with their diet and nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How have you been feeling emotionally during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Avery: Emotionally, my pregnancy was a real rollercoaster. Initially, I felt a mix of excitement and anxiety when I found out I was pregnant. It was something I didn’t expect, and while I was happy, I was also scared about what it meant for my life and future. 

As the weeks went by, the anxiety intensified. I constantly worried about the health of the baby and whether I was doing everything right. I felt isolated because I didn’t have a lot of support or anyone to share my feelings with. The stress of my financial situation added to my anxiety, making me feel even more overwhelmed.

After the miscarriage, I went through a period of deep sadness and reflection. It was hard to process the loss, and I often found myself thinking about what could have been. I didn’t really talk about it much with anyone, so I carried that emotional burden alone. 

I think emotional health is crucial during pregnancy, and I wish there had been more resources available to help me cope with those feelings. I’ve heard that many women experience similar emotional ups and downs, especially if they’re already dealing with stress in their lives. Have you come across strategies that help women manage their emotional health during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who supports you during your pregnancy? Can you tell me about your support network?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Avery: I wish I could say I had a strong support network during my pregnancy, but honestly, it was pretty limited. My family lives a bit far away, and while they were supportive from a distance, I didn’t have anyone physically close to talk to or lean on. I felt like I was navigating everything on my own.

I have a few friends, but they’re also busy with their own lives and might not fully understand what I was going through. I felt a bit isolated, especially when it came to sharing my feelings about the pregnancy and later about the miscarriage. I didn’t really reach out for help, so I carried a lot of those emotions by myself.

I think having someone to talk to who understands the challenges of pregnancy—whether it’s a friend, family member, or even a support group—would have made a big difference for me. It’s tough to go through such a significant life change without a solid support system. 

Have you seen any effective ways to help women build a support network during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about your birth plan? What are your preferences for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Avery: I haven’t really put together a formal birth plan since my pregnancy ended in miscarriage, but I did think about some preferences during my pregnancy. I imagined wanting a supportive environment where I could feel safe and comfortable. I was leaning towards wanting a natural birth if possible, but I also understood that plans can change, and I would be open to whatever was necessary for the health of the baby and me.

I think having a supportive healthcare provider who could help guide me through the process would have been important. I would have liked to have someone who could answer my questions and help me make informed decisions about pain management and any interventions that might be needed. 

Ideally, I would want my partner or a close friend with me during labor for emotional support, but since I’m single, that aspect was a bit tricky. I hadn’t really thought about who I would want there, which made me feel more uncertain about the whole experience. 

Overall, I just wanted to feel empowered and informed throughout the process. I’ve heard that having a clear birth plan can help women feel more in control during delivery. Do you think having a birth plan is helpful for women, especially those who might feel unsure or anxious about the experience?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What sources of information have you used to learn about pregnancy and childbirth?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Avery: I relied on a few different sources to learn about pregnancy and childbirth, especially since I didn’t have a lot of access to healthcare resources. I read a lot of articles online and found websites that provided information about prenatal care, nutrition, and what to expect during pregnancy. I also looked for forums where other women shared their experiences, which helped me feel less alone in what I was going through.

I borrowed some books from the library on pregnancy and childbirth, which were helpful for understanding the different stages and what to expect. However, sometimes the information felt overwhelming, and I wasn’t always sure which sources were credible. 

Social media also played a role; I followed some pregnancy-related accounts for tips and advice, but I found that it could be a mixed bag—some content was really helpful, while other things felt unrealistic or added to my anxiety.

I wish I had access to more structured education, like classes or workshops, especially since I didn’t feel comfortable asking questions during my one appointment. I think having guided information would have helped me feel more prepared. Have you found that many women rely on similar sources for information, and what do you think might be the best way to provide education to those who have limited access?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How are you managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Avery: Managing the financial aspects of pregnancy was definitely one of my biggest concerns. Since I was underinsured and living on a lower-middle-income, I had to be really careful with my budget. During my pregnancy, I worried a lot about the costs of doctor visits, tests, and any potential complications. I knew that healthcare could be expensive, and I didn't want to end up with a lot of bills I couldn't afford.

I tried to plan for basic necessities, but honestly, it was difficult to set aside money for things like prenatal vitamins and other supplies. I was mostly focused on day-to-day expenses, so I didn't have much leftover for pregnancy-related costs. I found myself relying on friends and family when I needed help, but I didn’t want to burden them, so I kept my worries to myself.

If I had been able to access more community resources or programs to help with the financial side of pregnancy, I think that would have made a big difference. I’ve heard there are some programs that offer assistance for low-income families, but I didn’t really know how to navigate that or if I qualified for anything.

Overall, the financial stress often added to my anxiety about the pregnancy. Do you think there are effective ways to support women financially during pregnancy, especially those in situations like mine?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How has your pregnancy affected your work or employment situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Avery: My pregnancy definitely had an impact on my work situation, even though I was only pregnant for a short time. When I first found out I was pregnant, I was really nervous about how it would affect my job. I work as an administrative assistant, and while my employer is generally supportive, I worried about needing time off for appointments and any potential complications.

During my pregnancy, I tried to keep my situation private, especially since I was still figuring things out and didn’t want to deal with any added pressure at work. I felt like I had to maintain my performance despite the anxiety I was experiencing. I didn’t want my colleagues or boss to see me differently or think I couldn’t handle my responsibilities.

After my miscarriage, I found it challenging to focus on work. I was dealing with a lot of emotional pain, and it affected my productivity. I didn’t talk to anyone at work about what I was going through, partly because I didn’t feel comfortable sharing personal matters. I think having a supportive work environment, where I could have discussed my situation without judgment, would have made a difference in how I coped with everything.

I’m still in the same position now, and since I’m not planning to get pregnant again, I haven’t had to think about maternity leave or anything like that. But it does make me wonder how other women navigate their work lives during and after pregnancy. Have you seen common challenges that women face in balancing work and pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about the postpartum period? What plans do you have for after the baby arrives?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Avery: Since my pregnancy ended in miscarriage, I haven’t made any specific plans for the postpartum period. However, I’ve thought a lot about what it would be like if I had a baby. I know that the postpartum period can be really challenging, both physically and emotionally. 

If I were to have a baby in the future, I would want to focus on recovery and taking care of myself while also being there for the baby. I’ve heard that it’s important to have a support system in place during that time, which I didn’t really have during my pregnancy. I think I would need friends or family to help out, especially in those early weeks when everything feels overwhelming.

I also worry about the emotional aspects of postpartum life. I’ve read about postpartum depression and anxiety, and I know that it can affect many women, especially if they feel isolated or unsupported. I would want to be proactive about seeking help if I started feeling down or overwhelmed.

Additionally, I would like to learn more about breastfeeding and infant care, as I know those are significant parts of postpartum life. I think attending classes or finding resources would be beneficial to help me feel more prepared.

Overall, I would want to ensure that I take care of my mental health and have a plan for any challenges that might come up. It’s hard to think too deeply about it right now since I’m not planning for another pregnancy, but I definitely recognize the importance of being ready for that stage if it happens in the future. Have you found that many women have similar concerns about the postpartum period, and what resources do you think could be helpful for them?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Thank you for your time and for sharing your experiences with me. This concludes our interview.
